Entry.1: Russian successes. Issue of Steel Helmets – Daylight saving in France
Entry.2: Big offensive apparently begins. Fierce artillery duel heard at Ypres.
Entry.3:
Further Russian successes – Presence of many Fokkers overhead.

"Our First real experience of German gas" (Gas used by Germans in counter attack at Ypres). Gas helmets worn for twenty five minutes.

June (1916)
Entry.5: Frenchy Sunday –attend Mass at 5.30pm (6.30 by watch) – Artillery at Ypres silent – 2 Taubes brought down – I leave with party for Bois-Grenier
Entry.7:
Huns shell Armentieres – Church set on fire by their shells – Seen by us at Bois-Grenier – wilful destruction. Very few cases - Death of Von Moltke

June
Entry.8:
(Longest Day (Daylight at 10pm and 2.30am.

More German destruction at Armentieres – I need a couple of Sydney Boys (H.H.) – Gas Helmet inspection – German shells land all round our building but fail to hit it. In steel helmets all but four of us evacuate to the trench.
Entry.9: Night Duty in D.R – Gas alert – We are warned of the approaching danger of gas, just as the alarms in the trenches ring out. – False alarm. Correspondence
Entry.10: Fritz quieter – Thunder storm. – soldiers from Balmain – Food Tres bon as is usual at Bois Grenier.
Entry.11: Cribbage – We return from Bois Grenier to Ft Rompu – A new "soccer" ball gives us plenty of sport.
Entry.13: First view of German soldiers. Three pass through our base. Our Boys successful raid.
Entry.16: I again meet Roger Morgan – Capt. Strachan annoyed by the Boys.
Entry.17: Preparations for evacuation of Ft Rompu.
Entry.18: We leave our "Good old home" at 10.30am for Bailleul – March not enjoyable owing to rapid pace heat of day etc – We arrive at our new quarters – very tired.
Entry.19:
Beautiful surroundings – Aircraft very plentiful. Bad state of Hospital etc

Big British offensive begins with great success. I journey to see Ed Cornish but without success. I view a "Taube chase".-
Entry.20: I see most of the town which is an important military base – Owing to C.C.S. being numerous the town has a great number of K.C. Cars
Entry.21: Receipt of home letters – The Big Offensive continues. Mother and Fathers "Silver Wedding").
Entry.22: Y.M.C.A. visited also R.C. Church near our billet – Work as usual
Entry.23: "Soccer" again – Y.M. & Canteen – British still doing well.
Entry.24: Last Day at Bailleul – preparation for departure.
Entry.25:
We leave for Unknown destination – After 7 kilos we pass through Strazeelle & thence on to Borre where we camp for night in barn. Very fine country (Hops, wheat, Vineyards etc)

Visit to church (1626) – Our billet originally in hands of British in a skirmish with Germans who occupied another farmhouse about 700 yards away – Germans driven out by Cavalry. Farmhouse shows signs of many bullet holes.
Entry.26: Glorious day for second stage of march – We leave Borre at Midday and after a march of 10 miles arrive at Ebblinghem – Pass the night in a huge paddock
Entry.27:
Our billet extra good – Country farmyard. During the day "B" & "A" section play one another football.

"A" section winning both games soccer 3 to 2 & Rugby 9 to 6. Myself a scorer in Soccer. "Great Day". – We are able to enjoy plenty of fresh Milk.
Entry.28: Reveille at 4a.m. (actually 3) – Our Ambulance moves off at 6am for Wizernes (8 miles) and there we entrain – We pass through Calais, & Boulogne (Cattle truck, - "High expectations of going to England" on passing out of Boulogne – Our journey completed at 9p.m at Saleux – a night march, in which we lose our bearings proves to be our hardest & heaviest work since landing in France. After 9 miles (chiefly hills) we halt till the morning (Mary exhausted) – Sleep on the Road.
Entry.29: Another 4 miles march and we are billeted till 5pm when we again leave for another village 5 miles away. Up to this point we have marched 50 to 60 miles since leaving Ft Rompu. Our new billets are very poor and 4 of us passed the night in a cart.
Entry.31: A large mail from home. Route march (6 miles) – During march we encountered Cavalry (British) who were training – Still farther on March we meet Mounted Machine Gun Corps (?)
Entry.32: Six months to day since we sailed from Sydney – more papers & letters from Home. Easy Day.
Entry.33: Sabbath & Letter writing and Lecture on Gas & gas attacks – Midnight trip to Amiens (N.Z. Hospital)
Entry.35: Feet & Boot inspection. Once again the "Ghost Walks"
Entry.36: Route march of 9 miles from our own village through Aerodrome on to Bertangles. We halt at the Aerodrome and are given our first opportunity to see planes stationary in act of ascending and descending. – Mail closed
Entry.37:
Once again we move camp – leaving Vaux for the village of Herissart – We are billeted with 25th Batt –

July 21st

Still at Herissart – On duty in dressing station – Mail.

July 22nd

After an easy day we move off at 10am, and after a rapid march of 6 m we arrive at Vadencourt.

July. 31
Entry.38:
21 28

Sept. 4 11. 18 25

Oct. 2. 9. 16 23.

July 23rd

Sabbath – We are now very handy to the firing line and throughout the day we have seen reinforcements & vast amounts of munitions going up to the Line, whilst car loads of our own wounded boys are proceeding from the Line.

During the previous night & to-day the 1st & 3rd Brigade A.I.F. captured in first attempt a village & wood which the Pommies failed to capture on six occasions – Visit to
Entry.39: F. Amb to see our wounded & German Prisoners. Presence of German Souvenirs
Entry.40: Despatch of Parcels to home. Our camp in the woods is proving a good one – German counter attack repelled by "our boys". Heavy bombardment heard all day & night.
Entry.41: Practice with the stretchers. Harry & I pay a visit to Contay and then to
Entry.42:
Fld. Amb – 600 passed through during the day.

Australians still attacking & holding their gains. Gen Birdwood daily visits the firing line. Our chief is very pleased.
Entry.43: After a good day we depart from Vadencourt & proceed towards the line of battle (14 miles away). On our way we pass vast numbers of troops, munitions etc. We end our march & bivouac on the outskirts of Albert.
Entry.44: Shortly after rising we meet & converse with many of the "first Brigade" who left the trenches the previous night after doing such wonderful fighting. – I again meet Billy Hain & Roger Morgan of the 2nd Batt. A.M.C. – In the afternoon I part from Harry & Rog who are in the Stretcher Party for trenches – Good luck be with them.
Entry.45: Our tent division return to Vadencourt & take over from R.A.M.C. a D.R.S – Plenty of work. (Night Duty)
Entry.46: Return of Pte Stock (Wounded) & news of Bert Mallet’s death etc.
Entry.47: Weather hot & depressing – The Anzacs continue their excellent work round Pozieres – I pay a visit to Eddie Cornish 45th Batt and have a pleasant evening – More casualties among our Ambulance.
Entry.48: Australia Day – First hand news from the trenches – News of Harry & others – A Hell on Earth – "Gallipoli insignificant" – Another visit to E.C. wherein I meet Capt. Perry & Lieuts Murray. Fergusson. McIntyre Storer.
Entry.49: Mail from home – Presence of numerous bomb-dropping Taubes. Quiet night on Duty.
Entry.50: Contay in afternoon. We receive many more of our boys from the trenches. Vivid stories from the line. Day of vast preparation by British. Enormous shell supply goes to Albert
Entry.51: More letters. Fierce night’s bombardment of Somme Front – incessant 12 hours shelling by our Artillery.
Entry.52:
Early morning (1a.m) celebration of Second Anniversary of Dec. of War.

Menu

Mashed Potatoes

Salad

Salmon

Cocoa

Biscuits

Fruit

Toasts

"The King"

"The Allies"

"The Day" x

"Our Fallen Comrades"

Second Division successful in a big objective – Fritz badly beaten.
Entry.53: Good news of previous nights attack all along the line. Continual stream of patients pass through our hands.
Entry.54:
Two more of our boys (making 4 in all) killed – Tragic but courageous end of Harry Smith – He, together with Pte Griffiths are recommended for D.C.M’s

Success of 2nd Division.
Entry.55:
Return of our bearers from Albert – The boys have done excellent work.

Losses killed 4 wounded 8

Praiseworthy speech by our Colonel & General Legge.
Entry.56: Heavy losses in Fourth Division – 1st Div reorganised – Patients galore
Entry.57: Pay-day – Departure of 20 men from our section for Puechvillers (?) Arrival of Reinforcements to supplement our Amb.
Entry.58: More Reinforcements – familiar faces from Liverpool – The King passes through two villages but does not pay us the visit we expected – patients arrive in hundreds – Anzacs good work
Entry.59: "Bon" news from all fronts. Continuation of night duties – A further advance by Anzacs.
Entry.60: Return of boys from Puchevillers and formation of "C" section.
Entry.61: Good news from both Russian and Balkan fronts – News of Eddie Cornish.
Entry.62: M’s Birthday – Rainy & miserable day – Fourth Division heavy losses.
Entry.64: Nothing of much interest except news from Russian & Italian fronts – Receipt of large mail from "Aussy".
Entry.65: Fourth Division relieved by First. Parcel despatched to home.
Entry.66: Our spare time occupied by "Soccer" – More letters to & from home.
Entry.67: Harry parsons – Keith Harris etc – Death of Jim Cunningham & 3 others 1st Fld. Amb.
Entry.68: Sabbath – Church "Confession & Communion" – Fifth Fld Amb relieved us at "Anzac Rest Camp
Entry.69: Our Ambulance moves off from Vadencourt to Albert where we bivouac for the night.
Entry.70: We make an early start for Becourt-Wood where we relieve 1st Fld Amb and take up our new duties. (Day-duty dressing room. "Serious cases.) Plenty of solid work – Indescribable wounds – (*North, Fusiliers)
Entry.71:
(Elsie’s Birthday) Many more serious cases

Our Dressing station formerly a private chapel. Family vaults under the chapel.
Entry.72: Another successful Anzac attack against the Huns. Our good work proceeds.
Entry.73:
As a result of the previous nights work we are extra busy. Our room resembling a slaughter yard – During the day we have one man killed & 12 wounded from our ambulance

Inspected by two Generals
Entry.74: Another of "our boys" reported missing. Busy as usual. Success of 21st Battalion in their night attack.
Entry.75:
Our bearers return to Becourt & we are relieved by 13th F Amb. We move off to Warloy via Albert and once again enjoy the sights of the historical Albert Cathedral & also the imposing statue in the town square

We are billeted at Warloy for the night –
Entry.76: Our Ambulance moves off & after a short march we encamp at Toutencourt. Either in T court or behind us is the remaining Aust. force, for being relieved by the Canadians we are all bound for a new front – Mail from Australia.
Entry.77:
In the worst

of weather (what with rain, cold & wind) we do a great march of 17 miles (7½ hrs) and arrive at Montrelet in a worn, wet & weary condition
Entry.78: A good nights rest makes us fit again. However strange to say we are allowed a days rest before proceeding with our journey.
Entry.79: Hill at Montrelet – During our leisure we are all given to letter writing – D.C.M.’s
Entry.80: I take a voluntary walk to Fienvillers & Candas (10kilos). Mail from home.
Entry.81: We resume our journey at 10a.m and after a march of about 8 kilos we arrive at village of Longuevillette. Billeted in hay sheds
Entry.82:
Spent quiet day in Longuevillette prior to entraining for (?) – 

(Apple fights)
Entry.84: Night march commenced 1am – arrive at Doullens station 3a.m. entrain 5am and after uneventful journey arrive at Proven at 2p.m. (First glimpse of Belgium March to Poperinghe – We encamp at Canadian Camp on outskirts of town in the vicinity if Ypres.
Entry.85:
Very pleased with new Camp – As we are in a very prominent position as regards German gas attacks, a most vigilant watch is maintained.

"Impressions of Belgium"
Entry.86: Special leave to Poperinghe with Roy & Harry. The day occupied in viewing Cathedrals etc – shopping & visits to Y.M.C.A. & Soldiers Club. Also in having photographs taken – We spend a most interesting day – A large mail makes a happy ending.
Entry.89: Route marches – Infantry drill – letter writing. (The two sisters)
Entry.90: We defeat the 6th F.H. in a Rugby match by 5 to nil – a good game – Pay & mail – Asher Chowne.
Entry.91:
A number of us do some hop picking for some Belgian womenfolk -

Waratah Camp

Set.
Entry.92: "Beau-coup" rain prevents anything unusual from happening
Entry.93: Third journey to town at Poperinghe, where we are sent to purchase footballs – in the afternoon we again defeat the 6th Fld. Amb at Rugby 2-0.
Entry.94: Close of mail. We won our first soccer match against Sixth by 5-1 – a good game – Harry & self represented our Unit – Issue & lecture on new type of Gas helmet.
Entry.95: "Sports day" is abandoned owing to another move of camp – We leave Waratah for Reninghelst (which is on the road to Ypres). Visits to Y.M.C.A & village.
Entry.96: Guard duties – Signs of the approaching winter
Entry.97: Neuralgia – visit to dentist. Continuation of good news & bad weather.
Entry.98: "Our boys" beaten at Australian Rules. Mail from Home.
Entry.99: We win our second game of Soccer, beating 4th Field Amb by 4 goals to nil – I spent the night at Y.M.C.A with Asher Chowne – Glorious weather.
Entry.100: Wet & stormy weather prevents work or pleasure.
Entry.101: A route march gives us our first distant view of the town of Ypres – In the afternoon we move camp from Reninghelst to Poperinghe.
Entry.102: Sabbath. "B" Section take over Divisional Baths – We are billeted in a Convent & have every convenience tending to make us comfortable, - Our handy position to town a valuable asset – but demanding a power of wealth. – Sports
Entry.103: "Talbot House" & Rev Clayton – visits to Y.M.C.A & town. Photos posted home – Daily hot & cold showers.
Entry.104: A busy day - Good news from England & the front.
Entry.105: "Our Canteen" – Parcel from Home – Aerial combats. Rumour of Combles & Thiepval.
Entry.106: Rumour confirmed – "Confession" – Belgian Priest – Card etc
Entry.107: Holy Communion & Mass – Ordinary Duties. "Peg O my heart"
Entry.109: Operation of time in Britain & France – A fine Soccer game in which the Tommies beat us 2 to 1 – Sight of burning balloon.
Entry.110: Our concert proves a great success – (Major Conrick?)
Entry.112: Visits to Y.M. & Movies together with usual work on. Baths constitute the best part of 48 hrs – "A Welsh Singer.
Entry.113:
Many old faces – our fourth Soccer match.

results in an easy win against the 6th 4-0 being the score
Entry.115: News of Roull. Laren – Jimmie Garner – New Respiration drill – The Canteen.
Entry.116: George & Stanley C. – Our third defeat of the Sixth F.A. at Rugby 3-0. – Our first experience of gas with box respirators.
Entry.117: Transferred from Baths Staff to Unit – In a most memorable match we defeat the Wessex R.A.M.C. at Soccer by 6-3. The Tommies play a very dirty game but have to take more than they can give. – "The match and After"
Entry.119: I make a start to complete "The Xmas Carol" – Mail closed for several days – Hospital
Entry.120: Still a patient – Wild rumours concerning A.I.F. – "Salonica" England etc. Letters & papers from Home.
Entry.121: My eye is slowly improving – Gramophone in the Hospital. Pleasant memories awakened by "Humoreske" – "Cornish Floral Song". – More Home letters
Entry.122: We revenge our only defeat in beating the 131st R.A.M.C. by 4 to 3. I find it much harder to look on than to play – "The pride of the 7th" –
Entry.123:
The injustice of our officers regard-

ing Mail.

-Rumours of England Salonika, Ireland. Gallipoli, Palestine & Somme.
Entry.124: Departure of first section of our Second Division – now the time has arrived we are very loath to leave our home in Poperinghe – Nothing happened of importance.
Entry.125: Day of Preparation – Abandonment of Shorts.
Entry.126:
We take to the road once more and in departing Poperinghe we leave many kind friends & the nearest approach of Home or Home Living, since leaving Australia – Only pleasant memories shall remain – "Belgium we salute you." Arrival at Steenworde where we are billeted.

French Market Day
Entry.127: Motor trip to Poperinge (Car orderly). Wet & cold weather.
Entry.128: Australian Mail – Route march to village of Eecke – outgoing letters still prohibited.
Entry.129: Our Ambulance leaves "Steenworde" & after passing through Cassel & other villages we finish our days march at Noordpeene still in doubt as to our final destination – Our billets the worst we have had in France – Weather very cold & unsettled – Farmhouse – Concert
Entry.130: Resume march from Noordpeene via the large town of St Omer and we are billeted at Pilques – Australian Mail arrives.
Entry.131:
Football etc – further mail

"Derancourt"

Xmas Cards Home etc.
Entry.132: We leave Pilques in very bad weather and after a tiresome march we entrain at 7pm at town of Arques – spend night in train.
Entry.134: End our journey & leave train at 5a.m. in the village of St. Riquier – Breakfast on station and march to Ergines. Billeted in Farmhouse barn – "Apples to burn" – Episode of the Two Fowls".
Entry.135: Reveille at 4.30a.m. Another miserable march – We motor in French Transports for about 80 kilos, passing through Flixecourt & Amiens & completing our journey in the vicinity of Albert. Frightful Billets - Winter with a vengeance.
Entry.136:
Signs of recent destruction in our village

- Respirator drill

- Referendum in Australia
Entry.137:
:-

First hand stories from trenches. Men dying from dreadful conditions – Improved & lengthened rail service evident. – Rain prevents work
Entry.138: First winter Rum issue – "Non-combatant" – Big mail from home – Bad weather continues much to our disgust. Driven from our beds by rain.
Entry.139:
First result of conscription voting to hand – Lads pleased with result – We move from Dernancourt to Becordel which is in the vicinity of the celebrated Fricourt. Fatigue duty during day – the whole countryside for miles & miles is one vast camp – Activity of our Aircraft - During the night a Taube flying very low cross our camp & drops many bombs in the near neighbourhood, killing

6 legs amputated

1 arm amputated

8.30 – 8.30

1 arm etc 

Many fractures

"The Referendum"

& how we took the result

& wounding many. It is driven back by our own anti-aircraft service.
Entry.140: Our "Section" – taken on strength of C.C.S. – Under canvas once again – Preparation of an "Operation tent" – We relieve 29th British Division.
Entry.141: Transferred to No.1 Operating Tent which is run by 15th Aust F. Amb – Long & gruesome days work – 8.30a.m. to 9.30p.m. – Operations.
Entry.142: Continue duties in Tent. No.1 – Assisting Capt. Brown, who impresses as being a thorough gentleman – Capt. Colyer of Newcastle also of Tent 1. – German "strafing" of Fricourt Wood. Remainder of our Ambulance relieve 15th F.A. up the line.
Entry.143:
Prevalence of bad weather continues.

French Yarns

by "Peter"

Prisoner of Zenda

-Old friends Cecil Moore & McDade – Letters despatched Home – Still on duty in Tent. 1. – "Aye indeed and ‘tis a bloody business – (At least Shakespeare would say so.
Entry.144: Transferred from No.1 to No. 3 operating Tent (Night Duties) – Under our own M.O’s. Very much regret leaving Capt. Brown who on my leaving makes a most kind proposal on my behalf – Afternoon free
Entry.145: Night Duty under Major Brendan & Capt Hamilton – Zeppelin raid 3 miles from camp. Loss of Ammunition. rain and Death of over 200 men in C.C.S. Caused by Zeps bombs – Busy night.
Entry.146:
Alick Barr – Seventh Brigade stunt – Death of Ray Walters & other of Sixth F. Amb.

2 Amputations

Emersons Essays
Entry.147: Another visit by German Aircraft – no damage – We lose Capt Hamilton – Despatch of Parcel (cards) – Quiet night
Entry.148: Day duty – Acquaintances renewed – 8th Fld. – Aust Mail.
Entry.149: Another quiet day – Rumours of Peronne – Still another visit by Taube – 37 patients killed or wounded in the Rest Station – No bon!
Entry.150: Quiet day (for us) – fine night unfortunately – German armoured train shells our camp without doing damage – lively time while it lasts.
Entry.151:
News of the Arabia – Reuben Lovelock – Our Camp No mans land prior to offensive! Our tent originally German Officer’s

Nov. 13th.

Success of 5th &
Entry.152: Brigade in charge this side of Bupaume – 3 of our Ambulance wounded – busy day at C.C.S.
Entry.153: Early morning visit by Taubes. Success of English N of Albert – Preparations for departure – Bed at 12p.m – Reveille at 5a.m.
Entry.154: Departure together with 50 bearers from 8th F.A. entrain at 8am and after passing through Fricourt Mametz etc we leave train at Montauban or Quarry Dump – "The Greatest Battle field of France – and what it looks like" – Our wealth of Ammunition etc – Congestion of traffic owing to frightful state of roads – "First glimpse of Tanks"
Entry.155:
The daring of German Aviators and the result thereof – "4 come down" – 1 bomb dropped within 100 yds of our camp kills 6 horses.

Third division in France

Longeval

Green Dump

& 2 men, besides wounding others. – Fatigue duties. Aerial Activity.
Entry.156: Freezing weather. Aust Mail – More Taube marauders – First fall of snow this winter –
Entry.157: "With our Boys in the Trenches" – Pitiable scenes & stories – British victories at Arras – A day of rain – More tanks – Our camp in a God forsaken spot
Entry.158: Another day of fatigues – first wash for 6 days – our 2nd experience of armoured trains – miserable weather
Entry.159: "Hypo" – "Roull" Laren – Death of Bill Mazey & others – "John Bull’s ferfi." – "Oh that armoured train" – Pick & shovel work.
Entry.160: Return of Bearer to the Quarry – Preparations for departure – A miserable train trip followed by a more miserable march – "Where are we? – Somewhere in France". The thoroughness of Fritz’s positions "avant l’offensive"! (Dugouts etc) – Back to the good old Huts.
Entry.161: We lose our O.C. much to our regret. We are all decidedly pleased to be away from the war & its Horrors – A trip to a neighbouring village - "Vaudeville".
Entry.162: General duties – News of "Britannic" – An expensive bath in Albert. – Promotion of Capt. Donald – Our air-service.
Entry.163:
Mail from London & Home – Our recent camp & its surroundings

Smithy’s friend Nobby Wallace

shelled.
Entry.164: Shelling of Albert – very bad weather – "Our Officers" – what we think of them!
Entry.165: A visit to Amiens – The first trip to & from – Trams. Buildings etc – First tram ride since Cairo – Many cards sent home – "The Cathedral & its magnificence".
Entry.166: Parcels from Home – Squad drill – Fritz on the Roads – also the Anzacs. Treatment of prisoners – miserable weather.
Entry.167: Long route march & squad drill – The irony of it all – Mail of 16 letters from A.S.W. – Xmas Cards – Bad news from Roumania – Sad news of Sid Goode.
Entry.168:
Nov. 29th

Why our chaps missed their daily wash – (water frozen in cart). Route march – Alteration of leave to England – preparations for departure.
Entry.169: Our Ambulance moves off & after a short march we entrain – Reinforcements for 1st Division – A slow but pleasant train journey – Episode of German . Leave train at 7p.m at village of Vindencourt and march to billets in La Chaussee
Entry.170: Another raid on London – Unsuccessful – Fatigues – A trip to Picquigny and a visit to the "Duds" Vaudeville Show – A versatile comedian & a "bon Orchestra – A meal earned by Patience but paid for by cash.
Entry.171: Sabbath – Attend mass at village church – "A Knight of the Church (?) Waggon guard for 24 hours - Clarke’s day-out.
Entry.172: A free day granted us after strenuous (?) guard duties – Letter writing – Better weather & the result on our boys – Assisting Q.M. Sergt.
Entry.175: Second Amiens trip – Padding the hoof.
Entry.177: I again meet E.C – 4th Div. School –
Entry.178: Soccer Match – Lost 3-0 – Sloppy game – Sherwoods –
Entry.179: Sabbath – Mass – Cold feet – Ancient custom in Church
Entry.180: E.C – Jimmy Driscoll – soldier & boxer – Return of Jimmy Steele & others to unit – Edmund Burke.
Entry.181:
Lt. Col Black joins Ambulance as C.O.

"Lays of Ancient Rome"

formerly Major Black of 14th Fld Amb. Route march of 8 miles.
Entry.182: Camp – guard duties. – Gas drill – A visit from General Legge.
Entry.183: Third trip to Amiens – pleasant day - weather cold but invigorating – a wait of 5 dreary hours for our train back to camp.
Entry.184: Gas drill – Snow fall – Mail from Home – camp fatigue duties – pick & shovel work. "Germany tries hard for piece – Noteworthy change in British Cabinet – Lloyd George as Prime Minister.
Entry.185: Surprise victory of French at Verdun – physical exercises & march – Mail to Home – (Cable)
Entry.186:
Sabbath – Attend Mass – Preparations for departure -

"The Moods of Ginger Mick"
Entry.187: At 4a.m. we move off & make first journey to again proceed to the Line – Entrain at Vignacourt at 9a.m & after 3 hours slow travelling we leave train & are billeted at Buire –
Entry.189: Snow storm – "A bath we did not get - & have we earned it" - Orderly room runner – A trip to Mericourt where we enjoy a vaudeville show – Charlie Chaplin again –
Entry.190: Orderly Room duties – Y.M.C.A. – bad weather – marching orders – L. George
Entry.191:
Our Ambulance leaves Buire at 8.30a.m

A long & miserable march under wretched conditions – We pass through Meaulte, Becordel. Fricourt. Mametz, and pass the night in the last named.
Entry.192: Reveille 3.45a.m – We march off in the dark through rain, mud, slush on a road half under water & stray mettle – After a solid march we arrive at a miserable spot in Bannefay Wood – Take up duties in A.Div. Much improved service directly behind the Line light railways.
Entry.193: Xmas Eve – A fine day but cold – distribution of Gifts - Taubes once more – Application for new position – News of Eric Gordon. A midnight meal.
Entry.194: Xmas day – No Armistice – but absence of shells, gives us a peaceful day. Xmas pudding issue – Nothing startling occurred.
Entry.195: Boxing Day – Asher Chowne – night duty – as usual – Fritz’s erratic firing – very few wounded cases but scores of "trench feet" pass through us. Capt. Power.
Entry.196: German shells & bombs near our camp. "peace" negotiations continue – night duties.
Entry.197: A Taube that caught us napping. Our bearers leave for – Sleep during day.
Entry.198: I meet one of the Fountains – trench feet – Artillery very quiet – Anxiety for mail – few cases
Entry.199: Artillery more lively – Anti-tetanus – Many of our troops go down to trench feet – wretched infantry conditions – Letter Home – Peace negotiations German bluff.
Entry.200:
New Years Eve

Artillery active at midnight – a couple of serious wounds & many trench feet – Otherwise quiet – 

The Last Day of the Darkest Year in History
